KZ.evidence: Kazakh Activist Detained On Eve Of China-Central Asia Summit
KZ.note:
Arrest of Activists in Kazakhstan Likely Linked to Criticism of Plan to Deport Chinese Nationals
https://www.rfa.org/english/news/uyghur/arrest-12172019163038.html

ALMATY, Kazakhstan—In early March, Serikzhan Bilash, a Kazakh activist documenting and advocating for Muslims caught up in an immense internment-camp system in China, was taken from his hotel room by security services and arrested.
https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2019/09/china-xinjiang-uighur-kazakhstan/597106/
https://foreignpolicy.com/2019/03/11/uighur-china-kazakhstan-astana/
KZ.answerer: Answered by Danil Bekturganov and Tatyana Sedova, and has been reviewed by Aksana Akhmedova

UZ.evidence:
But disaster struck on March 27 when Celil was detained by Uzbek authorities apparently acting on a request from China.
https://www.rferl.org/a/1069583.html

Uzbekistan’s invisible Uighurs: The plight of Uighurs is object of an unspoken policy of censorship.
https://eurasianet.org/uzbekistans-invisible-uighurs

Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, and Kazakhstan have all purchased cameras from Chinese corporations to monitor traffic and their citizens, in a bid to create “smart cities.” This technology, already used to track the movements of Uyghurs in their homeland, is proliferating worldwide.
https://uhrp.org/report/no-space-left-to-run-chinas-transnational-repression-of-uyghurs/
UZ.note:
Uzbekistan urged not to hand ethnic Kazakh over to China
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uzbekistan-china-businessman-idUSKCN1PX1H1/

The mysterious case of the missing Kazakh refugee
https://thediplomat.com/2019/02/the-mysterious-case-of-the-missing-kazakh-refugee/

Uzbekistan – Uighurs – Discrimination – Forcible return to China – Separatist movements
https://www.ecoi.net/en/file/local/1239103/2016_1298901616_uzb35765.pdf

MN.evidence:
"A prominent anti-China activist has been arrested in Mongolia, part of what campaigners have said is a wider effort to ""clean up"" Beijing's critics in the country.https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220222-prominent-anti-china-activist-arrested-in-mongolia

MONGOLIA: INVOLUNTARY RETURN OF DISSIDENT BACK TO CHINA, WHILE ACTIVISTS CRITICAL OF MINING PROJECTS FACE HARASSMENT
https://monitor.civicus.org/explore/mongolia-involuntary-return-of-dissident-back-to-china-while-activists-critical-of-mining-projects-face-harassment/"
MN.note: China and Mongolia have ratified a bilateral extradition treaty, but such requests typically involve lengthy procedures. There are no known extradition cases that have been carried out by the Mongolian government. https://safeguarddefenders.com/en/blog/chinese-police-kidnaps-writer-mongolia
MN.answerer: Answered by Dulamkhorloo Baatar, and has been reviewed by Ani Kintsurashvili

MX.evidence: In 2019, the anti-PCC activist Ai Weiwie visited Mexico to present a gallery in the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM, in spanish). In that moment, Weiwei did not put under arrest by Mexican government. Theferore, this Indicator deserves a "No" response.
MX.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Team Fundación Andrés Bello - Centro de Investigación Chino Latinoamericano

TR.evidence: Media reports and international rights groups say that houses of many Uyghurs have been raided, Chinese citizens of Uyghur ethnicity are detained and sent to extradition centres. Furthermore, Uyghur protestors and others who organised public protests in front of Chinese diplomatic missions in Turkey were detained several times based on Chinese Embassy’s requests. Rights groups warn about the increasing number arrests in Turkey against people who engage with political activism against China's policies especially towards its Uyghur population. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a "Yes" response.
TR.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

IS.evidence: Iceland does not have any extradition treaties with PRC.
IS.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

PT.evidence: There is no observation of the indicator phenomenon.
PT.note: On the contrary, the concerns of Portugal are regarding citizens who have both Portuguese and Chinese citizenship, either detained in Hong Kong or fleeing to Taiwan as the cases of  Kin Chung Wong (2022) and Tsz Lun Ko (2020) show.
PT.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

RO.evidence: We have not identified any case of request by the PRC to the Romanian government related to detaining people for committing a crime involving engagements with social movements or resistance activities in Hong Kong, Xinjiang or for other human rights or civic rights issues
RO.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Mădălina Voinea and Sorin Ionita

VN.evidence: Vietnamese government is known for arbitrarily detaining people who engage in political activism criticizing the local establishment. Occasionally, the criticism of China can be perceived as a potential threat against the local government, e.g. criticism of the Chinese political system, criticism of Chinese investments and industrial zones in Vietnam. Even demontrations against the Chinese territorial claims in the South China Sea are not received well as they are considered a potentially destabilizing factor despite the fact that the Vietnamese government itself objects and denies the Chinese territorial claims.
VN.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

NP.evidence: The Nepal Police regularly arrests Tibetans in Kathmandu for “questioning” during high profile visits by Chinese officials, and increases surveillance in Tibetan refugee settlements during cultural celebrations like the Tibetan New Year or Tibetan spiritual leader-in-exile Dalai Lama’s birthday. Even in 2023, Nepali police arrested a Tibetan refugee with Nepali citizenship.
NP.answerer: Answered by Sriparna Pathak, and has been reviewed by Amish Mulmi

TH.evidence:
In 2017, the Thai government deported about a hundred Uighurs to China, despite facing strong criticism from human rights organizations both in Thailand and abroad.

In 2023, more than 60 self-exiled members of a Chinese Christian church who had been briefly detained in Thailand were released after paying fines, amid fears of deportation to China.

In a separate case, in 2015, Gui Minhai, a Hong Kong bookseller, disappeared in Thailand, only to reappear in China without his passport.
TH.answerer: Answered by Pravit Rojanaphruk, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

MM.evidence: Most of the detainess were slapped with charges relating to scams and online fraud.

ID.evidence: The case of detaining Uyghurs in Indonesia and deporting them to China has led to speculation that there is collusion between the Chinese and Indonesian governments. Indonesia should be able to rehabilitate and provide protection to the Uighurs even though they are considered a syndicate of terrorists. Their actions are most likely due to the pressure that the Chinese government is putting on Xinjiang.
ID.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

KH.evidence: Yes, there is evidence to support the claim.
KH.note:
The editor-in-chief of the Chinese-language online news platform, Angkor Today, was expelled and deported to China yesterday after he published an article saying Cambodia was selling China-aided COVID-19 vaccines on the black market.

Cambodian authorities have returned to China a group of ethnic Uyghurs who had sought asylum here, despite international concern that they could face torture and execution for allegedly taking part in deadly ethnic riots in China.
KH.answerer: Answered by Bradley J. Murg, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.
